- Board: 3♦ 8♦ A♠ 6♦
- We now have a pair of sixes (6♣ 6♦) with J♦ kicker, but four diamonds on the board puts every opponent who has *any* diamond as having us out-kicked with any flush—even if the diamond is a deuce.
- We block no nut flushes and have exactly zero fold equity versus any made flush; jamming or betting risks stacking off dead.
- Even against a hand like A♥K♠ (no diamond), we’re behind; the board texture is completely barren for us.
- Villain checked back flop in position—range still includes all diamonds and all Ax (which improved to trips). We can’t credibly represent any strong value.
- Size of pot (40) relative to stack (980) means we lose little equity by checking.

We should not put another chip in—no value, no bluff, no equity versus the key parts of villain’s range.

rounds.response:
[Player 1] Flop analysis:

- Board: 4♦ 7♣ 4♥  – paired board with flush/straight draws possible.
- We hold 7♠ 4♠ → a full house, fours full of sevens. This is among the strongest made hands possible.
- Pot is small (60), effective remaining stacks are 940–1000. We want to start building a pot ASAP.
- Villain (out-of-position small-blind) donk-bet 20 chips. Their range is wide and capped after limping pre-flop, so they can have plenty of bluffs/semi-bluffs (flush draws, straight draws) as well as some weak straights/7x/44–77. Our full house crushes them all.
- Raising allows us to extract value now and set up stacks for later streets. I’ll size a bit larger than pot to charge draws yet allow worse boats like 77 to continue.

Target stack commitment: ~70-90 chips keeps future streets simple (pot-size turn shove roughly).

[Raise 80]
